burn out.translation[0].definitions[0].d: if a fire burns out or burns itself out, it stops burning because there is no coal, wood etc left
burn out.translation[0].definitions[0].e: He left the fire to burn itself out.
burn out.translation[0].definitions[1].d: if a building or vehicle is burnt out, the inside of it is destroyed by fire
burn out.translation[0].definitions[1].e: The hotel was completely burnt out. Only the walls remained.
We passed several burnt out cars.
burn out.translation[0].definitions[2].d: to remove something by burning it
burn out.translation[0].definitions[2].e: The cancer cells are burnt out using a laser beam.
burn out.translation[0].definitions[3].d: to work so hard over a period of time that you become unable to continue working because you are tired, ill, or unable to think of any new ideas
burn out.translation[0].definitions[3].e: It’s a high-pressure job and you could burn out young.
He was almost burnt out by the time he was 21.
She’s in danger of burning herself out.
burn out.translation[0].definitions[4].d: if an engine or electric wire burns out or is burnt out, it stops working because it has been damaged by getting too hot
burn out.translation[0].definitions[4].e: The plugs are wired so that if one burns out, the others will still start the engine.
I think you’ve burnt out one of the gaskets.
burn out.translation[0].definitions[5].d: if a rocket or jet burns out, it stops working because all its fuel has been used
